paper_title: Construction of a CsPbBr<sub>3</sub> modified porous g-C<sub>3</sub>N<sub>4</sub> photocatalyst for effective reduction of CO<sub>2</sub> and mechanism exploration

catalyst.llm generation: flake-like porous graphitic carbon nitride (P-CN) and CsPbBr 3
catalyst.source: Herein, a novel photocatalyst composed of flake-like porous graphitic carbon nitride (P-CN) and CsPbBr 3 is fabricated via a high temperature calcination and freeze drying method.
catalyst.context: In-depth research of the active sites and charge transport behavior is an important topic for investigating photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 .Herein, a novel photocatalyst composed of flake-like porous graphitic carbon nitride (P-CN) and CsPbBr 3 is fabricated via a high temperature calcination and freeze drying method.The experimental results show that P-CN/CsPbBr 3 has a superior CO 2 reduction efficiency, and that the yield of CO reaches 30.39 mmol g A1 , which is about 7.2 and 1.2 times higher than those of the primary B-CN (4.2 mmol g A1 ) and CsPbBr 3 (24.4mmol g A1 ), respectively.The improvement in photocatalytic performance is mainly ascribed to the heterostructure, which can promote the separation of photogenerated carriers, and the porous structure of P-CN, which can improve the absorption capacity of CO 2 .This study provides a significant method for the construction of efficient g-C 3 N 4 based photocatalysts to reduce CO 2 .

catalyst.source: In summary, a porous g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction photocatalyst loaded with CsPbBr 3 (P-CN/CsPbBr 3 ) is successfully synthesized.
catalyst.context: In summary, a porous g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction photocatalyst loaded with CsPbBr 3 (P-CN/CsPbBr 3 ) is successfully synthesized.In comparison with B-CN and CsPbBr 3 , the CO yield of P-CN/CsPbBr 3 is significantly increased to 0.3039 mmol g A1 , which is about 7.2 times and 1.2 times higher than that of B-CN and CsPbBr 3 , respectively.It should be admitted that the enhanced photocatalytic CO 2 reduction properties can be attributed to an accepted fact that the porous structure can increase the specific surface area, expose more active sites, and enhance the adsorption capacity of CO 2 .Meanwhile, the synergistic effect between the P-CN and CsPbBr 3 heterojunction can improve the carrier concentration and accelerate charge separation and transfer, which has been proved by photocurrent, PL, FL and EIS analysis.Therefore, our work offers a highly efficient photocatalyst for CO 2 reduction and provides a new perspective for the research on porous g-C 3 N 4 based catalysts. reaction medium.source: Photocatalytic CO 2 reduction in the liquid phase is performed in a custom-built glass reactor with a 300 mL volume.
reaction medium.context: The chemical reagents used in this experiment are melamine (99), dodecanol (99), sodium dodecyl sulfonate (98), gum arabic, Cs 2 CO 3 (99), octadecene (90), oleic acid (AR), PbBr 2 (99), oleylamine (C18: 80-90), and n-hexane (97), all purchased from Aladdin Chemistry Co., Ltd, while ethanol (C 2 H 5 OH, 95) is purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.Deionized water is used throughout the whole experiment. 3.0 g of melamine is put into a crucible, and then transferred to a muffle furnace and calcined at 500 1C for 2 h.Afterwards, it is heated up to 550 1C for another 2 h with the heating rate of 2.3 1C min A1 .Finally, bulk g-C 3 N 4 (B-CN) is obtained. Initially, 0.3 g of Cs 2 CO 3 is added to a mixed solution containing 40 mL of octadecene and 2.5 mL of oleic acid, and dried under vacuum at 120 1C for 0.5 h.It is then heated to 150 1C until Cs 2 CO 3 reacts completely with oleic acid.After this, 0.21 g of PbBr 2 is dissolved into 15 mL of octadecene in another beaker.1.5 mL of oleylamine and 1.5 mL oleic acid are injected into the above solution.When the PbBr 2 is completely dissolved, the mixture is heated to 150 1C and 1.2 mL of Cs-oleate solution is quickly injected.30 s later, the mixture is cooled in an ice water bath.Finally, the product is washed in a centrifuge with n-hexane several times and dried at 40 1C for 12 h. In experiment 2.3, when PbBr 2 is completely dissolved, B-CN is poured into the mixture, and then the temperature is increased to 150 1C.The other steps are the same as experiment 2.3 to obtain B-CN/CsPbBr 3 .Subsequently, 0.5 mL of dodecanol, 0.2 g of sodium dodecyl sulfonate, 0.2 g of gum arabic and a certain amount of the above mixture are scattered in 10 mL of deionized water.After stirring at 60 1C for 20 min, the compound is frozen for 24 h.Subsequently, the mixture is placed in a vacuum freeze-drying machine to freeze for 24 h.After this, the samples are dried at 100 1C for 24 h.Finally, the products are washed in a centrifuge with ethanol several times and dried at 100 1C for 24 h.The content of B-CN/CsPbBr 3 is 0.05 g, 0.2 g, 0.3 g, and 0.4 g, respectively, and the samples with different contents are labeled as P-CN/CsPbBr 3 -1, P-CN/CsPbBr 3 -2, P-CN/ CsPbBr 3 -3, and P-CN/CsPbBr 3 -4.The method for preparing porous g-C 3 N 4 (P-CN) is the same as that of P-CN/CsPbBr 3 , except that B-CN/CsPbBr 3 is changed to B-CN. The crystal structure of the photocatalytic material was studied using a Bruker D8 X-ray diffractometer, equipped with a Cu-Ka radiation X-ray source, which was scanned in the range of 10-801 at a rate of 71 min A1 .The structure and chemical bonds of the molecule were studied by FT-IR (Magna-IR 550).The surface chemical valence state of the catalyst was studied by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, EScalab 250A).The morphology and structure of the materials were characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM2000-CX) nd scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JSM-7800F).The UV-visible diffuse reflectance spectroscopy of the photocatalytic materials was determined using a UV-visible diffuse reflectance spectrometer (UV-3600) with BaSO 4 as the standard substrate.The measurement range was 200-800 nm.The specific surface area and pore diameter of the photocatalytic materials were analyzed using an automatic specific surface and porosity analyzer (NDVA-2000e).The optical properties of the photocatalyst were analyzed using a photoluminescence detector. Photocatalytic CO 2 reduction in the liquid phase is performed in a custom-built glass reactor with a 300 mL volume.Cooling water from a chiller is passed through the jacketed wall of the reactor to control the temperature at 25 1C.A 300 W Xe lamp is used as a light source.First, 0.05 g of photocatalyst is dispersed in 100 mL of deionized water in a glass reactor under magnetic stirring.Before light irradiation, CO 2 gas is brought into the above solution for 10 min to eliminate air and to build up a saturated CO 2 solution.Subsequently, the lamp is turned on to start the photoreaction.During the reaction process, photocatalytic materials were taken from the enclosed light at 1 h intervals.The type and content of the product were measured every 1 h using a gas chromatography (GC-7920, China) detector.The isotope labeling experiment used 13 CO 2 instead of 12 CO 2 , and the products were analyzed by gas chromatography mass spectrometry (GC-MS, 7890A and 5975C, Agilent).
